Caption: Fig. 1: SPSC on synthetic dataset of uniformly sampled 20, 000 random points at surface of 5D sphere. (a) Radial standard configuration of star coordinates with hyperbolic curves corresponding to conditions (2) and (6). (b) Shape of multidimensional sphere is preserved in projection. (c)–(f) Breaking one of the conditions when moving an axis along one of the curves leads to distortion of the shape in projection. Scalar product and lengths of vectors x and y are displayed in the left-upper corners. (g), (h) Compensatory movement of the green axis restores the imposed conditions for arbitrary displacement of axis attr1. The resulting shape in the projection view is a sphere again.

Again, k is not fixed during interaction, but coordinates shape preserving, when the user interacts with the light we always pick the k that minimizes the distortion of the constellation. blue axis. Fig. 3: Approximating 2D scatterplot for “Ecoli” dataset: (a) In contrast to OSC, SPSC allow an axis (here alm1) moving beyond the circle of unit radius. When the compensatory axis (alm2) is fixed, it is extended in an orthogonal direction relative the interacted axis. Displacements of both axes are shown as black lines. (b) The projected data layout approximates the respective bivariate scatterplot. Data classes are color encoded. A circle of unit radius is shown for reference.

Fig. 4: Impact of different SPSC strategies on axes and data distortion for “Ecoli” dataset: Starting with a PCA configuration, axis gvh is stretched. For each strategy of selecting a compensatory axis, we show the resulting displacements of the star-coordinates axes (left column) and the projection views (right column). Magnitudes of compensatory displacements of the projected samples are encoded in color linearly varying from white (no displacement) to red for the displacement length 0.26 and above. Minimal compensatory displacements measured in l∞ -, l1 -, and l2 -norms were achieved when applying the least distortion of projected data strategy.

Fig. 6: Evolution curves for (a) the length scale and (b) the error functional from [18] are presented for different strategies of selecting the compensatory axis. “Wine” dataset was used for the experiment shown in Figure 5. The best length scaling strategy results in values of the error functional better that the ones reported for OSC in [18]. Note that length scales close to 1 and error functional values close to 0 are only a design goal for the best length scaling strategy and no quality measure for others.

The best length scaling strategy results in values of the error functional better that the ones reported for OSC in [18]. Fig. 8: Morphing for “Parkinsons” dataset. Initial constellation is presented in (a). The axes’ trajectories for a shape-preserving morphing are shown in the star-coordinates (c) and the dual-coordinates views (d). Depending on the number of active axes, the morphing takes different number of steps to complete, see (b). Choosing the number of axes between 5 and 9 provides a reasonable balance between the morphing speed and its gradual behavior.
